top_comment.text:
Having played Fallout 3 New Vegas, ands the DLC's... The lead in about the 
US government starting the war which devastated the world is wrong.. The 
game deliberately is ambiguous about who started shooting nukes first.. the 
implication, after China lost their invasion of Alaska.. they did so in a 
cataclysmic act of defiance..
.
But if you read most of the materials, logs.. it becomes clear they want 
everyone to find their own conclusion.. as there are hints that just about 
everyone in any position of power was either corrupt, or stone cold evil..
.
1. The US government is shown becoming extremely authoritarian
2. The Chinese, just as evil as we have known communist China to be.
3. Every corporation is run by psychotics experimenting on other human 
beings.
4. religious groups are displayed as cults, dangerous... except for the 
Mormon survivors who still remember their Christian past.
5. Mothership Zeta.. one prisoner log explicitly tells the aliens were 
torturing an American officer for the nuclear strike codes..
.
No. 5 is the compelling one in my view... The US won in Alaska.. China was 
beaten, retreating, but secure in their own country.. the Corporations,.. 
might, might have had the ability.. but no clear motive.. the religious 
cults lacked the ability.. but.. aliens who had been observing man for 
centuries.. suddenly wanted the launch codes?..
.
Full disclosure, I'm a USAF vet, assigned as a security forces SP nuclear 
weapons security at a SAC missile base, FE Warren AFB during the last years 
of the cold war.. I read everything, and know quite a bit about the history 
of it.. the game is fun.. and touches the occasional nerve... but I enjoyed 
it a lot.. I just don't see the US and China being so crazy as to start WW 
III in a fit of anger.. not rational.. and I know that the president before 
a launch order is obeyed, must have verbal confirmation from two cabinet 
level officials that he/she is unimpaired, rational.. not under duress.. a 
drunken president couldn't launch a strike.. the system is designed to 
block that.. true this is just a fictional game.. but seriously.. it just 
makes more sense that the grey aliens caused the war to devastate humanity 
so they could claim the Earth..
.
so no.. I don't believe humans caused the war.... they did everything to 
make it possible.. but didn't strike the match..﻿

comments.text:
I find that a majority of gamers who i meet online like to complain. 
Fallout 3 is a terrible game, resident evil is terrible, AC and COD have 
been grouped together as terrible, star wars is now a universe to avoid 
because disney kills everything, mass effect is ruined and a bunch of other 
games are getting shit. What really bugs me is when people talk about how 
back in their day there were more creative games. I go back to ps2/xbox 
era(about the era i started playing games) and I find platformers and 
platformers. further back and there are clones of games. more platformers 
like super mario bros and more games copied from dragon warrior and other 
games. if we go further back then there are hundreds of pong clones. I am 
still wondering where the good creative times are. I have been playing 
nes/snes games for a couple of years and it seems like a pattern to me. 
Sure there are a few nice interesting games and even the clones are really 
nice even if the plot is really the only difference. or if there is a 
slight change in gameplay. but i don't find the games super ultra creative. 
It's just a part of the twisted way that publishers work. You find a 
company making money from zelda. What do you do? You make a Zelda clone.

comments.author: SinerAthin

comments.text:
+SinerAthin
True... Except that the target population for the FEV is humanity, of which 
the Enclave is a part. So long as the Enclave lives, the virus would have 
hosts that it could infect.

Also, while it is true that a virus can "die out" without host cells for 
them to infect and use to reproduce, many viruses can and do "survive" 
outside without a host. That's how they infect others. The length of time 
that they can do this for varies between viruses, but there are some that 
can go dormant and survive for hundreds of years without a host.

Considering the fact that the Enclave got their samples of the FEV from the 
Mariposa Military Base after the fall of the master nearly 75 years prior, 
I think it's fairly safe to say that the virus could survive on it's own 
for at least a decent amount of time, making infection after the initial 
viral wave possible.

I think it's time to put this debate to rest though. We've gone on for a 
while and we're starting to veer into other topics. Since I can see this 
going on for way longer than it's worth, let's just agree to disagree in 
regard to the Enclave and call it a day.

This has been fun though. I don't normally get to have YouTube 
conversations like this. Take care. I'll see ya around!
comments.author: Aaron Wilson

comments.text:
+Aaron Wilson

The interesting thing about viruses is that there is this thing such as a 
"Too deadly" virus. 

A virus that kills too quickly and efficiently is likely to kill off its 
target specie, and thus also itself.
It needs carriers as no virus can survive forever in the world.

Like we've already seen, the FEV virus is a really effective killer. Maybe 
too effective killer.

When released into the world, it is likely that it would have killed off 
the vast number of inhabitants, before fading away.

Sorta like a biological nuke that devours itself.
comments.author: SinerAthin

comments.text:
That only further suggests that they should've asserted their dominance 
earlier, instead of resorting to genocide. In fact if they had, the people 
emerging from the vaults might've been more willing to listen to them, as 
it would've been closer to the time after the bombs dropped and the people 
might feel a greater connection with their former government.

Also, them holding off further increased their technological superiority 
compared to the Wasteland. If you think about it, any progress that the 
wasteland makes is from working with the broken down (and in some cases 
irreparable) technology of the past. They were all things that the Enclave 
had, and unlike the wasteland, the Enclave had the technology in working 
order and a team of elite scientists to constantly work on improving it. 
That would put them leagues ahead in the long run, though that's besides 
the point.

An interesting tie in. I'll admit that if the Enclave had done that, their 
actions would've been less reckless than if they had not. There's nothing 
in the lore that suggests they did this though. Interesting fact: Turns out 
that the Enlcave's FEV was actually more indiscriminate than we thought. It 
killed pure humans too. It just took longer. (14.5 hours) The Enclave was 
also going to spread the virus world-wide, meaning they were planning to 
wipe out EVERYONE except themselves. Heck, they might've even wiped 
themselves out in the future, given the nature of the virus.

Finally, radiation can kill anything with enough exposure, viruses 
included. But radiation damages nucleic acids, which can cause mutation in 
anything with a nucleic genome. (viruses fall into this category) This 
makes the chance of the FEV mutating quite possible, especially since the 
radiation of the wasteland is more expansive than intense. (With the 
exception of some pockets of course)
comments.author: Aaron Wilson

comments.text:
The Enclave didn't need to wait in order to have their technological edge.

After the bombs hit, everyone else were reduced to the stone age.
In fact, the longer they waited, the more time the Wasteland had to deviate 
from the thing that had once been America, and groups opposed to the 
Enclave had a chance to spring.

*Metro: Last Light Spoiler ahead*

Regarding the Viruses, it reminds me of the weaponized virus from Metro: 
Last Light.

To keep the story short, it was a weaponized biological virus with a set 
'expiration' date.
This meant that after a certain period of being unleashed, the virus would 
lose all effect and essentially kill itself.

What this meant was that you had a weapon with the indiscriminate killing 
power of a virulent pandemic, yet controllable without the need for major 
quarantines or extensive cleanup programs.


And lastly, radiation actually kills viruses. It doesn't make them evolve 
or mutate any faster.
In fact, radiation is used in medical science as a way to deal with viruses.
comments.author: SinerAthin

comments.text:
+SinerAthin
Haha! True that.

And no, perhaps it did not appear to be unstable at first. It may very well 
have been perfectly stable when they released it into the jet stream or 
through project purity.

Funny thing about viruses though; they have a tendency to evolve. Just 
because the virus is only targeting those exposed to radiation now, doesn't 
mean it won't be doing something else 20 or even 10 years down the line, 
especially when you consider that they are releasing it into the radiation 
soaked wasteland, which is a breeding ground for random mutation.

What's more, they weren't even administering it in small doses to specific 
populations. They were going to release it into the air. It would've fallen 
everywhere; the water, the soil, any mutated animals that may have been 
used for livestock... Nowhere would be safe. If the virus changed and began 
attacking indiscriminately or perhaps reverted to it's original purpose and 
began mutating those infected into super mutants, what would the Enclave do 
then? Was that even taken consideration before they approved this act of 
mass genocide?

Of course not, because again, they are warped at their very core. They 
weren't worried about the ramifications of releasing a deadly toxin into 
the air. They only cared about eliminating the "muties". (And taking power, 
which, despite all their anti-mutant talk, is what I believe is their true 
motivation) That's the only way such a thing could be approved. Because 
anyone with half a rational mind and any knowledge of science would've seen 
the litany of problems that could come as a result of their actions. That 
alone proves them to be short-sighted and reckless.

Again, you're giving the Enclave and their "struggle" more credit than 
they're worth. While the FEV was a virus at its core, the Enclave culling 
strain was far more comparable to a dose of cyanide than a plague. It was 
so toxic that a 0.001% aerosol solution of the stuff could kill someone 
with minimal radiation exposure in under an hour. (And that's a nukepedia 
stat taken from Fallout 2. I'm not making that up.) This was not going to 
be "hundreds of years". They would've wiped out the populace in a matter of 
days, if even that long. And while it is true that the Enclave held off 
before showing themselves, it was only so they could ensure their 
technological superiority to other groups in the wasteland.

This goes back to my former point, which was that the Enclave didn't need 
to resort to this method. If anyone could handled the challenges of the new 
world, it was them, making it all the more outrageous that they would make 
a move to wipe out the populace (in such a reckless manner no less) without 
even trying other methods.

Long story short, even if you subscribe to the Enclave's twisted vision and 
morality, their chosen method of attaining this "New America" can not in 
any way, shape or form be considered rational. Aside from it being 
unnecessary and extremely callous, it was at the very least short-sighted 
and at the most downright irresponsible.
comments.author: Aaron Wilson

comments.text:
+Aaron Wilson

That's probably because many of the concepts, ideas and problems one can 
create in the realm of theoria or an imaginary setting can often be drawn 
from, inspired or applicated to possible events in the real world :P

I don't think the FEV virus was as unstable as you make it out to be, for 
while its development was fraught with difficulties, it seemed perfectly 
effective in Fallout 3 without affecting radiation free humans.

And I wouldn't say that the Enclave didn't think about the consequences.
In fact, they seem to be all about the consequences. Wiping out the base 
population and rebuilding the entire wasteland anew means that they are 
looking pretty far into the future, as it would take hundreds of years.

We're talking about a group who was ready to wait hundreds of years through 
a nuclear apocalypse in order to achieve the society they wanted ;)

Now that's a long-term goal oriented group if you ever saw it.
comments.author: SinerAthin

comments.author: VineFynn

comments.text:
+SinerAthin
Haha! I know. Funny how passionate we can get about a fictional 
organization, huh? :P

Well I do. Remember, when the Enclave was talking about wiping out the 
"muties" they weren't talking about marching into the wasteland and killing 
them. They planned to release a modified FEV into the jet stream over the 
wasteland and wait for the toxin to kill everyone off. I don't see how that 
could even come close to being as difficult as uniting the wasteland via 
diplomacy/force. The only challenging part would be the development of the 
FEV strain, and given the Enclave's technology, creating a toxin seems like 
squandered potential. They could focus their efforts into finding a way to 
reverse the effects of radiation and cure the "muties" or find ways to 
prevent any mutations from being passed on to the next generation. (Both 
more benevolent goals)

And no, I don't think there would be. The FEV would've wiped out most of 
the populace. That means the NCR, the BoS, the Legion... poof! Gone. Or if 
not gone, then at least reduced to a state where any resistance would be 
pointless. The only people who could've potentially challenged them 
afterward would be the remaining vault dwellers, and frankly, with the 
military might of the Enclave, I feel that would be more of a slaughter 
than a war.

Perhaps that is what characterizes the Enclave, but that doesn't justify 
their position. If anything, it undermines it, seeing as compromise and 
inclusion of various groups were some of the primary principles upon which 
the nation they claim to be representing was founded. Also, diplomatic 
behavior is hardly as risky as releasing an experimental virus into the 
air. That could've backfired in so many ways, both immediately and in the 
long run. It was downright reckless, which again, shows just how warped the 
Enclave is if they felt it was the "best solution".

Again, even if they felt that their organization were the most fit to rule, 
their endorsement of wiping out the entire wasteland without consideration 
for the consequences of such an action or looking into less extreme options 
proves that they aren't, especially since out of all the groups in the 
wasteland, they were the best equipped to pursue these alternative options. 
(Hopefully this is a bit shorter. Lol!)
comments.author: Aaron Wilson

comments.text:
+Aaron Wilson

That became a long post :P

Though I don't agree with the logic of calling them lazy. In fact, starting 
from scratch would probably include even more work.

There'd be wars either way.

I think what characterizes the methods of the Enclave are their lack of 
compromises, and taking no chances, hence them favoring a clean slate start.

They believe that it would be much more efficient & safer to rebuild the 
nation out from their own organization, rather than attempting to integrate 
different groups that have already developed a long way since the great war.

Their way of thinking is the complete opposite to that of the NCR, the 
latter making compromises as they attempt to include the other groups. The 
Enclave probably view such behavior as risky and self-destructive to the 
integrity of the nation.

comments.text:
+Galvorn11 In addition to the tags and special boosts, you'd have your race 
boosts. Vault Dwellers get a boost in intelligence, as well as boosts in 
medicine, science, and speech. Vault Dwellers can use their reputation for 
unique dialogue, and start off with a pip boy. Raiders get a boost in 
agility, as well as barter, lock pick, and small guns. Raiders can use 
their reputation for unique dialogue, and you can interact with most of the 
other raiders. Super mutants and Ghouls would be immune to radiation, 
however only irradiated items can heal them. Super mutants would have the 
highest damage resistance, but armor would be almost non existent for them. 
Super mutants get a boost in both strength and endurance, but only get 
boosts in big guns and melee weapons. New ghoul related side quests become 
available, but others close. Ghouls get a boost in both charisma and luck 
ironically, but only get boosts in repair and survival. Ghouls find more 
materials to scavenge, and can repair similar items with each other. 
Replicas get a boost in perception, as well as energy weapons, repair, and 
science. Replicas have a greater line of sight, can repair similar items 
with each other, but can only heal with scrap. I think this, with unique 
story lines for each race, an awesome environment in the northern mid west, 
all in conjunction with the things the past two Fallouts have brought us, 
would make a game they'd be talking about for many many years to come.

comments.text:
+Matt Miller To be brutally honest, I don't think that either the Enclave 
or the Outcasts have enough resources to go to war with the Eastern BoS in 
almost any of it's iterations as of 2281. The Enclave is, at best, a 
disjointed band of high-tech raiders with a military structure, at worst? 
They're just individuals fighting a losing battle. The Outcasts may be in a 
better position, but indications from Veronica seem to give the idea that 
the war with the Outcasts in the Capitol Wasteland ended sometime in the 4 
years between 3 and New Vegas.

I honestly think the Enclave needs a break. Really, it does. If they bring 
back the Enclave they should wait a game or two, make it remotely plausible 
that they could regroup and recuperate or just have them be wiped out 
entirely. They've had multiple organization-breaking defeats. The Oil Rig, 
the loss of Raven Rock, the loss of the Purifier, and the destruction of 
the Base Crawler. At this point, I wouldn't be surprised if they were wiped 
off the face of the map in the grand scheme of things. They've had their 
time. It's time to pass the torch to newer, better, more varied groups than 
the Enclave. They were good villains, to be fair...but now we need 
something better. Something more.

more interesting, but aside from the occasional vague speculation he adds 
in (for the story telling affect) you can actually find all of this stuff 
in the games themselves.  It takes a little digging, but its amazing how 
much lore you can dig up by just looking around through

comments.text:
The debate wether video games are just another form of storytelling or 
primarily made for, well, gaming purpose, is as old as the video game 
itself. You're not gonna suddenly resolve it here, in this comment thread. 
Some games are more of an interactive fiction than anything else. Some are 
all about having fun and trying to win, which is the essence of a game or 
playing something. RPGs are traditionally more story-oriented than other 
types of games, mostly because they come from the old pen-and-paper variety 
where the big deal was to create your own epic story. But even in 
pen-and-paper RPGs some players are more focused on building their 
character stats, having fun with their skills than paying attention to the 
story. So the duality is already there in pen-and-paper RPGs ... Mostly, 
any fiction you can build yourself and participate to becomes partly a 
game, because you have the choice to decide where and how it goes. Freedom 
of choice in an alternative fictional universe means you're playing. 
Telling stories and playing are both as old as humankind itself and there's 
no end to this debate. Video games are no exception.
comments.author: Feamelwen

comments.text:
+bigdaddybouncer687 I mean gameplay as in a game like a FPS or platformer. 
RPG's are mostly about building stats. Not much different from a an old pen 
and paper RPG. Fallout 1 and 2 are like this. That is why RPG's usually 
have better stories.
comments.author: WulfOne

comments.text:
+WulfOne what do you mean there isnt much gameplay in an rpg? that doesnt 
really make much sense. every rpg ive ever played has hours of gameplay, 
whether its found exploring, discovering how i can play the game my way, or 
just enjoying the story. but the fact of the matter is, story isnt the only 
part of a game. its what separates games from all other art forms. youll 
find that most games (even the greatest ones that your nostalgia goggles 
have led you to believe) have sacrificed story to some extent for gameplay. 
gameplay isnt about graphics, violence, and gore, as youve so eloquently 
stated, its about a range of things, from fluidity of combat, to the 
strategy of resource management, and in the case of an rpg, creating your 
own unique way to play. frankly if you think gameplay is all about violence 
and gore, i feel bad for you, you must have fused with your nostalgia 
goggles and refuse to embrace anything that doesnt vaguely resemble the 
stuff you played in your childhood.
comments.author: bigdaddybouncer687

western RPG

+Slade Wilson Fallout is giving you the option to make the choice of what 
is good and bad. I will refer back to Junktown in Fallout 1 with Killian 
Darkwater and Gizmo the crime lord. It is stated at the end of the game in 
the slide show that Killian Darkwater enforces a style of brutal frontier 
justice. The game makes it seem like Gizmo though not a good person would 
be more relaxed. While Killian would be strict. That is the point Fallout 
is trying to make. This carries on into Fallout 2 with the NCR. Not many 
people like the NCR. The NCR would be a big government nanny state type of 
government and it wouldn't sit well with people who are used to the anarchy 
and lawlessness of the wasteland.

top_comment.text:
I'll always stay loyal to the Enclave. I served as what I like to call 
"Eden's Apostle" in Fallout 3. Here is my story. Sit back and enjoy reading 
this. It'll take a while, but it was the best run I've had in my six years 
of playing. I wiped out all Brotherhood of Steel Soldiers, Ghouls both 
Feral and Domestic, and Mutants. The aforementioned groups include Star 
Paladin Cross, Charon, and Fawkes. All with Dogmeat by my side. I helped 
the people of Megaton, seeing them as hard-working Americans who were 
deserving of life. I let the Ghouls take over Tenpenny Tower to destroy the 
Supremacists who inhabited it. Before killing off the Ghouls themselves and 
confiscating all worth while inventory inside to take with me. Leaving 
Tenpenny Tower to rot. I then moved on to Rivet City. I killed Zimmerman 
and his Guard after receiving A3-21's Plasma Rifle. I later disposed of all 
Rivet City Security members including Harkness and Commander Danvers. I 
killed them so that Rivet City could be easily controlled by the Enclave. 
Besides, Rivet City residents were worthy of life as they conducted 
research and Abraham Washington had a Collection of Historic Documents that 
should be preserved and appreciated as such. I then traversed the wastes 
until arriving at the Republic of Dave. I aided in the Election of Rosy to 
end Dave's Hierarchy. I followed Dave to a secure location before offing 
him. Leaving his body to fester in the harsh sun of the wastes. Arriving 
later at Galaxy News Radio, I aided those pathetic BoS Soldiers in 
defeating the Mutants in the battle to the Radio Station. Of course I 
allowed the Behemoth to kill all Brotherhood of Steel Soldiers possible 
before killing the monstrosity with the Plasma Rifle. Confiscating the Fat 
Man and all it's Mini Nukes for a future collection so that no further 
Radiation could be spread. I went on a quest for Three Dog to retrieve a 
Satellite Dish for his station. Thinking that he was worthy of the life he 
had been given, I complied. Then, I arrived in the Mall Plaza. Avoiding 
certain Destruction by the Muties outside, I ducked into the Museum of 
Technology to retrieve the Dish as well as complete the puzzle for the 
Xuanlong Assault Rifle for later. I would later cleanse the Area after 
being better equipped for the War that lay there. Returning to the open 
Wastes after placing the Dish for Three Dog. I found the Areas known as 
Paradise Falls and Temple of the Union. I quickly earned the trust of the 
Slavers after gaining entry via enslaving three Individuals. I quickly 
disposed of the fools and set all the Slaves free except the Ghoul. Whom I 
killed. After working for the Leader of the Temple of the Union. I 
recovered all the Lincoln items at the Museum of History. Killing all Feral 
Ghouls that stood in my way. I then disposed of all the Slavers at the 
Lincoln Memorial and disarmed all the mines surrounding it. Letting the 
people know that I had retrieved the Reference Picture and that the Slavers 
were no longer a threat. I allowed them to live as they swore to rebuild 
the Memorial. Which they did. Returning to the Museum of History. I 
discovered the cesspool known as Underworld. I met a Doctor who had a human 
girl in his care. Her name was Riley. She informed me that her Team, the 
Riley's Rangers, were trapped and needed help. I got Riley out of there and 
aided her team before accepting a quest from a ghoul named Mister 
Crowley. This led me to kill off or in some cases bargain for some keys 
from Ghoul Haters. I saved only one because he was a citizen of Rivet City 
and he was young. The key holders gave me clues that led me to a hidden 
bunker and warhead warehouse where I retrieved some Advanced Power 
Armor and Confiscated all Weapons and Ammo from the two Armories nearby. I 
returned to Underworld, working for another ghoul named Ahzrukhal to off a 
ghoul named Greta. After that, I received the Contract of a Ghoul Servant 
named Charon. Charon killed his former boss and I led him outside. Directly 
outside the Museum, I killed Charon. As well as the Ghoul who wandered 
around the Metro station in front of the Museum. I returned to Underworld 
for the Final Time to cleanse the Area. I.E. Murder every single Inhabitant 
in Underworld with the exception of Cerberus(A Military Robot) who secretly 
hated the Ghouls. Leaving him to guard the place from future undesirables 
inhabiting the Area. Along the way, I had discovered a place known as Fort 
Independence. Inhabited by Brotherhood Outcasts. Originally, I let them 
live. But refused to bring them any supplies. Later, Eden said that they 
were no better. So I killed them all and raided their Armory. Taking 
everything worth while. Including Alien Power Cells, Missiles, Mini-Nukes, 
and a Special Missile Launcher. This led me to the Town of Andale, a 
Cannibalistic Town which I quickly cleansed of its criminally insane 
people. Leaving the local Elder, who didn't eat other people, to raise the 
Children the correct way. I eventually met with a child named Bryan Wilkes, 
he'd lost his Father. So I chose to help him out in solving what had killed 
his Father and I made it a personal obligation to kill whoever caused it. 
Discovering it was Genetically modified Giant Ants, I found notes on a 
Computer owned by a Doctor Lesko. The Ants had been given the ability to 
breathe Fire. I ducked into the Metro Station, where Lesko had been hiding. 
After killing the Fire Ant Nest Guardians. I disposed of the Queen. Then 
turned my gun on the Robot inhabiting the same room. I then looked at 
Lesko's Terminal and destroyed the serum that had caused this terrible 
event. I returned to Lesko and he offered me a Genetic Enhancement after 
giving me an extra incentive in his old Lab Coat. I refused the 
Enhancement. I was not letting some Doctor inject me with some Mutagen. I 
was not becoming a Mutant. I shot Lesko and then found a home for 
Bryan with his Aunt Vera in Rivet City. Finally satisfied with the 
situation in the General Wastes. I set out to gain entry to the Citadel and 
cause an Implosion of the Brotherhood of Steel. Ending their foolish game 
once and for all. I began working for Doctor Li, the chief Scientist at 
Rivet City. Her clues about my Father led me to the hidden Vault beneath 
Smith Casey's Garage. After receiving a Vault suit, I entered a simulation 
that I quickly terminated with the failsafe. Reunited with my Father. We 
ran to the Jefferson Memorial which I had cleansed of Mutants earlier. 
Along with the Scientists of Rivet City. We began quick reconstruction of 
the Project known as Project Purity. As I completed the preparations. 
Vertibirds began landing at the Memorial. My brothers in arms had arrived. 
 Avoiding all Enclave Soldiers so that I would not kill these obviously 
trusted Soldiers. I went to the Purifier Room. Where my Father had a 
confrontation with the Colonel of the Enclave. Ultimately deciding to fight 
the Enclave at the cost of his own life. As he fell to the ground. I looked 
down upon him and said "You picked the wrong side Dad..." I escaped the 
Facility with Rivet City Scientists. Leading me to the Citadel where we 
gained entry and I met the Elder of the BoS. He allowed me to learn how to 
properly use Power Armor and I quickly rose in the Ranks until it reached a 
head at the siege on Project Purity. Prior to this, I had met a Super 
Mutant named Fawkes. Whom I used to take the blows as I tailed behind to 
eliminate all other mutants. I confiscated his Special Super Sledge and 
retrieved a Garden of Eden Creation Kit. Or G.E.C.K. for short. As I left, 
I was sedated by Colonel Autumn and Two Enclave Elites. Awakening in the 
Raven Rock Bunker. I had no choice but to refuse to comply with the Colonel 
as the President seemed adamant toward him. Traveling through the base, I 
met with Nathan. A Megaton Citizen whom I had treated well as he reveled in 
support of the Enclave. With his uttering of "They aren't who they say they 
are!" I turned my trusted Plasma Rifle upon him and yelled "Traitor" as I 
ended his life swiftly. The Colonel soon turned the Enclave against me 
despite the Presidents wishes to speak with me in peace. I fought through 
these Soldiers who seemed to serve the Colonel more then my Leader, 
President Eden. We eventually met face to face. I accepted his presence as 
an Artificial Intelligence and complied with his order to take the F.E.V. 
Virus and pocketing it. I spoke as long as I could with my Leader before 
bidding him farewell for the first and final time. I kept in mind that he 
had a growing dispute with Colonel Autumn. Confident to dispose of the 
Traitor named Autumn, I set out to the Citadel. We now arrive at the siege 
on Project Purity where I aided those Brotherhood of Steel idiots. I met 
Colonel Autumn and then shot him in the interest of preserving the further 
infection of his poisonous tongue that had corrupted the Enclave in 
Washington D.C. before inserting the F.E.V. Virus into the Purifier 
and Sacrificing myself in the name of the Enclave. Waking up two weeks 
later. I was disappointed to see that the Brotherhood had survived. I 
agreed to aid them further in the interest of not raising suspicion and 
immediately returned to Raven Rock for further orders from my Leader, John 
Henry Eden. When I arrived, it had been sealed up beneath collapsed rocks 
and rubble. Convinced it was the work of the BoS. I worked with increased 
vigor. A Lone Wolf fueled by Vengeance only accompanied by my furry friend 
named Dogmeat. I worked for the BoS. Destroying the remnants of the Enclave 
who continued the work of Colonel Autumn as contact with the President was 
impossible. I was forced to destroy what I had loved, so that I may rebuild 
it as Eden had wanted it. My quest led me to Old Olney, a Deathclaw 
infested cesspool that held a secret bunker beneath it that led to a Store. 
I would make this Bunker my home. Ensuring that the Relics of American 
History I had collected along the way would be safe from harm. Guarded on 
the surface by the Deathclaws, and beneath by Mines and myself when I was 
home. At the end of our story, I was led to Adam's Air force Base. Where I 
was forced to combat tons of Enclave Traitors. Killing them all, far and 
wide across the base. Not a single Traitor lived. I walked up and down the 
Area at least three times. I then boarded the Enclave Air Craft Carrier I 
had been sent to destroy. I fought and killed every single Traitor before 
reaching a Missile Launch Sequence Computer. I was sent here to launch it 
at the Enclave Air Craft Carrier that I was inside and then flee before 
they were able to strike. However, I had another option. The Citadel. A 
smile came across my face. I chose the Citadel before boarding a stolen 
Vertibird with the BoS Elder's Daughter and others. When we arrived, much 
to my delight and their dismay. The Citadel had been destroyed. With my 
furry friend by my side. We finished what I had dreamt of all along. We 
annihilated the last members of the BoS in Washington D.C. including the 
Elder's Daughter, Sentinel Lyons. Upon entering the gate to the Citadel. 
The building was completely gone. Leaving a mysterious Door at the bottom. 
Instantly, I remembered Eden's story about the BoS having access to some 
Military Grade Tech. I entered the Door to discover the Pentagon's Armory. 
A place long forgotten, buried beneath the Citadel. I retrieved Callahan's 
Magnum from a Safe as well as taking every piece of Weaponry there so that 
no lowly raiders could take this beautiful technology. Returning to my 
bunker beneath the city of Old Olney. I placed all my American Artifacts in 
secure locations. Placed all of my Medical Supplies in the Office 
Downstairs. I kept my Radaway with me, as I had never gotten Radiation 
Poisoning once and never intended to. I was never going to be a mutant. I 
stay there, keeping my Unique Items and Weapons with me at all times. 
Colonel Autumns Coat serves as my Clothing at my Home in the Bunker and 
the Winterized Combat Armor salvaged from a Simulation of the Operation in 
Anchorage Alaska. The Combat Armor never breaks and serves as my 
exploration outfit. This ends my story as President John Henry Eden's 
Apostle.﻿

captions.text:
You've experienced the FALLOUT series in your
own way, but want to learn more about its

story. Well- to get to the heart of the story-
you have to go back to the beginning...

As far as anyone knows, this wasteland is
the best damned wasteland in the world. When

America and China went head-to-head two hundred
years ago, both sides launched everything

they had and most people assume that China
was blasted back to the Stone Age. The only

way to know for sure is to jump in a boat
and paddle across the ocean so folks just

assume that China, Europe, Canada and the
rest of the world got hit at least as bad

as America did. People look out at this land
and some of them just know in their hearts

that it's the garden spot of the whole world.
Maybe that's why we can't go more than few

decades without someone trying to take over
the place.

When humanity was just beginning the struggle
to rebuild after the war, there was no sign

of the government helping out. People formed
tribes lead by the strongest warriors and

the smartest scavengers. The chain of command
and the line of succession meant nothing to

people who needed things done fast. The closest
thing to a government that emerged was tribal
elders, or the mayors of small villages.

Eventually, in 2189, some of the larger towns
in California banded together and formed the

New California Republic, but they never claimed
to be THE government. With no communications

from the pre-War government for over a century,
the memory of it faded as new generations

replaced the old, convinced the old president
and his kind were long dead, but the wasteland
ain't so lucky...

Two hundred years ago, in the last days before
the Great War, a secret coterie of America's

top-ranking political and corporate leaders
decided to duck and cover – big time. They

scurried right off the continent and hid inside
a secret offshore base then cowered there

while the rest of the country suffered a nuclear
holocaust the government had caused.

There they stayed, safe and hidden for decades,
and the group we know today as the Enclave

is the result of ten generations of breeding
between politicians, military brass, and corporate

executives. The direct descendents of the
people who caused the apocalypse? Not many

people would make up a story like that, so
it's probably safe to take them at their word
about their ancestors.

Regardless of who their great grandparents
were, the Enclave certainly has access to

an abundance of pre-war tech and weapons.
They hoarded it on a man-made island - a metal

city that grew out of the ocean floor. It
was once used to refine oil, back when people

could pull oil right out of the bottom of
the sea. The Poseidon Oil rig was inaccessible

to people on the mainland, so no one knew
they were out there until they began their

plan to rid the wasteland of everyone who
didn't fit their definition of a real American.

The Enclave had spent decades learning to
improve upon pre-war weaponry- they weren't

just collecting artifacts of the old world
like the Brotherhood, they were looking toward

the future. They had devices more advanced
than anything seen in the wasteland, including

the Brotherhood. It wasn't just better guns,
or the ginchiest armor – The Enclave had
a fleet of flying vehicles they called Vertibirds.

Most folk had never even seen a car move unless
it was hitched to a team of brahmin, so these

Vertibirds gave the Enclave an edge over every
other human group in the wasteland. They could

send in drop teams to kidnap whole villages
at a time to use as test subjects. They could

suddenly appear at remote locations, then
just as quickly disappear. Most importantly,

they could travel to and from their offshore
base secure in the knowledge that no one could
follow.

Well, almost no one. There was a person back
then who seemed to have a knack for getting

vehicles up and running again. People who
lived in the Den swear up and down that somewhere

around 2242 they saw a person in a Vault jumpsuit
driving around in an old Chryslus Highwayman

– with a big green mutant taking up the
entire back seat, and a cyborg dog poking
his nose out the window.

That's the sort of tall tale that would be
easy to dismiss, but it happened in the same

year someone managed to get a ship seaworthy
again. They sailed that tanker right out into

the ocean to the Enclave's base and took them
down.

Stories like that – they fill a body with
hope, maybe with enough work we could all

be driving around in pre-war cars, living
the good life. In a way, that sort of hope

for the future was what the Enclave wanted,
and they got it at the cost of their own lives.

Their ambition was their downfall. They weren't
content to live out their lives in prosperity,

they had to take back their country from the
people they viewed as sub-human. To do so,

the Enclave engaged in the sort of daredevil
science that brought about the end, the Great

War. They engineered a virus tailored for
genocide, performed inhuman experiments, and

even took to playing God by creating a species
of intelligent deathclaws – just like their

ordinary brethren, they were giant beasts
that could rip a man in half, but smart enough

to think like you and me and even mimic human
speech.

But even deathclaws were nothing when compared
to the Enclave's deadliest creation... A man

named Frank. It's hard to say just what Frank
Horrigan was. People who saw him in person

tended to die quickly and gruesomely. At some
point he must have been a man, a brutal killer,

but still human. But when the Enclave discovered
the old Mariposa military base and the Forced

Evolutionary Virus vats within, Horrigan was
exposed by accident. He was among the first

of a new generation of super mutants created
years after the Master's downfall.

The arrogance of the Enclave's leaders led
them to believe that they could improve upon

the virus. The FEV and Horrigan were used
for horrid experiments that would make the

Master cringe. When they could learn no more
from his suffering, the Enclave turned Frank

into their most devastating soldier, a mutated
cybernetic terror encased in their finest
power armor.

It's hard to imagine how anyone managed to
defeat arguably the most dangerous being to

ever walk the wasteland and bring down his
Enclave masters... But somehow the “Chosen

One” of an obscure northern tribe destroyed
the Enclave oil rig, forcing the Enclave to
flee New California.

Leaderless and directionless, they soon rallied
behind Autumn, a senior scientist who was

contacted by a new Enclave President. It didn't
take long for the remnants to reach the East

Coast with their Vertibirds. They had no fancy
oil rig this time, but they soon nestled into

Raven Rock and Adams AFB, pre-war bases that
were nearly as impregnable. They changed their

routine in Washington DC, promising that they
could guide America back to the golden age
of malt shops and drive-in movies.

On the West Coast, they had a man who claimed
to be the rightfully elected President of

the United States, but by the time they reached
the Capital Wasteland, things had changed

a little. Now their “President” remained
unseen and only addressed the public through

a swarm of floating propaganda robots that
spewed “Stars & Stripes Forever” along

with political rhetoric so hollow that it
sounded like it was written by a random word
generator.

The war for control of the Capital Wasteland
was a trial for the Enclave. Bereft of their

island fortress, and without the unstoppable
brutality of Frank Horrigan, they had to fight

a hard war to gain territory. The Brotherhood
of Steel had a strong presence in Washington

DC, and super mutants roamed the streets looking
for humans to abduct.

The Enclave still had their technological
superiority, and their Vertibirds. They even

took control of pre-war satellites, and could
fire missiles that had been waiting in the

sky for hundreds of years. But, their greatest
weapons were deceit and manipulation. The

Brotherhood relied on a local wanderer for
help in combating the Enclave, and it is possible

that the Enclave managed to convince this
individual to implement a more subtle plan

that could accomplish their goals even after
their repeated defeats at the hands of the
Brotherhood.

Yet it did not save them. In 2277, following
their disastrous defeat by Liberty Prime at

the Purifier, the Enclave was shattered again
and with its leaders dead or missing, its

major strongholds were soon annihilated by
Brotherhood strikes. The few surviving members

probably wish that they had stayed hidden
on their private island out in the Pacific.

Now the once mighty remnants of America's
elite have been reduced to a handful of wistful
old men hiding out in the wastelands.

Most gave up on the Enclave's vision of the
world, and settled down to live quiet lives,

getting as much peace as a person can in the
wasteland. Travelers who visit a certain old

motel in Novac can speak with a former Enclave
pilot who isn't as bad as the legends make

the Enclave sound – she's a tough old broad,
but she's no Frank Horrigan.

Out East the Enclave continues to operate
in small bands that harass the Brotherhood,

and anyone else who strays too closely to
their remaining outposts, but they are devoid

of leadership or any long-term plans. In the
West, sharp-eyed travelers can sometimes spot

the rusted hulks of crashed vertibirds, but
there is little else remaining of the Enclave

- or at least that the Enclave wishes to reveal.
Could an organization with such resources

be entirely stamped out? Much like radroaches
the Enclave has shown remarkable resilience,

and the people of the wasteland should be
prepared to deal with another hidden nest
of these relics of the old days.

For now, the Enclave has joined the ranks
of those who fancied themselves the rightful

rulers of the wasteland. Their glory has faded
along with that of others like The Master,

but it seems like some lessons are never learned,
and there's always someone new looking to

claim our wasteland as their own. The New
California Republic has flourished even as

the Enclave faded. And while the NCR has ruled
their lands with relative peace and prosperity,

even this period of stability is threatened
by a new would-be tyrant that seeks to rebuild
yet another fallen empire....
But that- is a story for another day.
